Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: COSEE: Ocean Communities in Education And social Networks (COSEE-OCEAN)
Award.AbstractNarration:
The University of Massachusetts, American Society of Limnology and Oceanography (ASLO), New York Hall of Science, and Boston Public Schools propose a thematic COSEE Center, that will greatly broaden the impacts of the COSEE Network. COSEE-OCEAN will use existing social and professional relationships to strategically engage ocean scientists in education and outreach activities by offering them professional development workshops at annual ASLO meetings and connecting them to COSEE Network outreach activities. COSEE-OCEAN will efficiently leverage these existing networks to expand and enhance a two-way exchange of innovation, experience, educational products, professional development models and best practices between COSEE and mainstream STEM formal and informal education communities.

Our vision is that within five years, all ocean scientists will be aware of and have access to education and outreach opportunities within the COSEE Network; the COSEE Network will be able to exchange knowledge and resources with STEM programs nationwide; informal education institutions will have increased their capacity to address public ocean literacy; and a model for implementing a high quality ocean curriculum in diverse, non-coastal urban school districts will be widely disseminated.

Our goals are:1)To engage more Ocean Scientists in high quality education and outreach opportunities provided by the COSEE Network, 2) To deliver high quality Ocean Science instructional materials to a diverse audience in large urban school districts, especially in non-coastal states, and 3) To promote Ocean Literacy through a network of Informal Science Education institutions and individuals.

Intellectual merits of COSEE-OCEAN are to strategically strengthen the interactions between existing networks in order to catalytically utilize COSEE resources in a broader context and to gain capacity from the networks' output, COSEE-OCEAN aims to reach ALL ocean scientists, to target under-represented minority students in urban school districts, to effectively engage students in non-coastal states, and to form connections between existing educational networks.

Broader impacts of this proposal include expanding the COSEE Network to include existing networks of ocean scientists (ASLO), informal educators (ASTC, CAISE), and urban educators (Lawrence Hall of Science and Boston Public Schools), which will strengthen the capacity of that overall network to deliver high quality ocean education to K-12 and public audiences. By using distance learning and working with urban school districts in non-coastal states, we will vastly broaden the reach of COSEE to include a diverse population of students who do not have opportunities to directly experience the ocean. In addition, we will link effectively with COSEE-China to extend the reach of COSEE beyond US borders.

POR.DRECONTENT:
COSEE OCEAN was a 6-year partnership between the University of Massachusetts Boston (UMB), the Association of the Sciences of Limnology and Oceanography (ASLO), the New York Hall of Science (NYSCI), and the Boston Public Schools (BPS) formed to increase the number and engagement of ocean scientists involved in education and outreach activities, and to increase the number of K-12 students and adults involved in ocean science.  A number of networking strategies were employed to efficiently and sustainably link scientists with educators and the public. 

To engage scientists, UMB and ASLO worked to shift the culture of annual Aquatic Science Meetings and Ocean Sciences Meetings (with 3000-5000 attendees) to provide high quality education and outreach workshops. To date, over 25 high quality workshops have been facilitated at 7 international conferences directly impacting approximately 750 ocean scientists, but more importantly, the meeting participants, young and old, are expecting to have excellent professional development opportunities at all future ASLO-sponsored meetings. In addition, 10,000 “Best Of COSEE Hands-On Activities” CDs were distributed to ocean scientists worldwide. The >50 engaging, foolproof activities for all ages are being used by scientists to interact positively with children in a wide array of settings including afterschool programs, classroom visits, and science fairs. To ensure that future ocean scientists are well-versed in education and outreach, Science Cafes have been established that to date have provided support network and career pathway opportunities including ocean education and outreach for over 400 graduate students. All of these programs are being sustainably offered as NSF funding comes to an end.

To engage children, UMB and BPS (56,000 students; 50% low income; 48% English as a second language) assessed, piloted, and adopted ocean science curriculum at Grade 5 and Middle School district-wide. For the foreseeable future, approximately 50% of the elementary students and 80% of the middle school students in BPS will receive some ocean science that is sustainably integrated into the overall BPS science curriculum and aligned with the Next Generation Science Standards and Massachusetts State Science Frameworks. Maybe more important is the establishment of a model for ocean scientists and educators to integrate ocean science district-wide, especially in a high needs, urban district, to increase the diversity in the ocean science community.

To engage adults, UMB and NYSCI formed a blue-ribbon panel of informal science educators and published a report entitled, “Opportunities for Creating Lifelong Ocean Science Literacy” which has been distributed to 300 informal science educators and downloaded an additional 1000 times. Clearly, this high quality summary of Ocean Literacy state-of-the-art is in high demand. As a result of the report and other COSEE activities, ocean literacy is being spread through a wide-array of traditional and non-traditional venues and media including museums, aquaria, buses, trains, songs, artwork, video, radio, and games.

Overall, all of COSEE OCEAN’s work continues to yield intended results beyond NSF support. The ocean science community, the informal science education community, and urban schools have been positively and measurably impacted to increase ocean literacy.
